content: How can I help you today?
I’ve been having a really hard time sleeping lately. Work is super stressful, and I just can’t shut my mind off at night. My partner thought I should come talk to someone about it.
Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like juggling both work stress and trouble sleeping has been overwhelming for you. What has this experience been like for you recently?

It’s been exhausting, honestly. Work has been so stressful that I’m constantly thinking about it, especially at night. I’m worried about what’s going to happen if layoffs come, and it feels like I can’t catch a break or stop my thoughts from spiraling.

That sounds really tough—feeling exhausted and caught in a cycle where work stress keeps your mind racing, even when you’re trying to rest. With all the worry about potential layoffs and the pressure you're under, it makes sense that shutting off those thoughts at night might feel so difficult. How do you usually manage stressful times like this?

Honestly, I don’t think I’ve been managing it well. I just kind of keep everything inside and try to push through it, but it’s not working anymore. I feel like I’m just carrying it all around with me, and it’s wearing me down.

It sounds like you’ve been trying to handle this all on your own for a while, and now it’s starting to feel too heavy to keep carrying. That can be exhausting. The fact that you're here shows strength—that you're open to talking about it and exploring a way forward. What do you think might help you begin to ease some of that burden?
I honestly don’t know. I’ve never really done this kind of thing before, so I’m not sure what would help. I just know I don’t want to feel like this anymore, especially for my family’s sake.

Acknowledging that you don’t want to feel this way anymore is an important step toward change, and it shows how much you care—not just for yourself, but for your family as well. Even though this is new for you, you’re taking a meaningful first step by opening up here. What kinds of things have helped you feel calm or centered in the past, even if just for a moment?

I honestly don't know. I've been so stuck in this stress and overthinking that I can't even think of what's helped in the past. I feel like I'm just in survival mode all the time, and it's hard to remember what calm even feels like.

It’s understandable to feel stuck when stress takes over like this—it can make it hard to remember moments of calm or even imagine feeling differently. Survival mode can be draining, especially when it lasts a long time. Looking forward, what kind of ways might you hope to reconnect with that sense of calm again?

I don’t even know where to start. I guess it could be small things, like spending time with my kids or trying to get outside more, but even those feel hard to enjoy right now because my mind is always somewhere else. It’s like I can’t ever fully relax.

Thank you for sharing that—it shows a lot of insight that you recognize how your mind being elsewhere is affecting your ability to enjoy those moments with your kids or get outside. It’s understandable that even the small things might feel hard when you’re carrying so much worry. What do you think could make those moments feel more accessible or peaceful for you?

I guess if I could somehow quiet my thoughts or not feel consumed by all the stress, I might be able to enjoy those moments more. But I don’t really know how to turn my brain off, and it feels impossible when everything at work is so uncertain.

That makes so much sense—when work stress feels all-consuming, it can seem nearly impossible to quiet those thoughts and find peace in the present. It sounds like finding a way to quiet your mind, even just a little, could be a valuable step for you. Would you like to explore strategies together, or is there something else you’d like to focus on first?
I’m open to exploring strategies if it could help, but honestly, I’m not sure what would even work. It feels like my brain just won’t stop, no matter what I try.

Being open to exploring is a great place to start—even when it’s hard to imagine what might help. Would it be alright to take a moment to reflect on how your sleep or stress might connect to your daily habits? These reflections might offer new perspectives or ideas for calming your mind. If you'd like, we can even review some step count or sleep data, as it could provide insight into patterns or adjustments. Would you like to include that in the conversation?
I’m open to reflecting on my habits, but I feel like I’ve already tried everything I can think of, and none of it has worked so far. But if you think it could help, I’m willing to give it a shot.

Thank you for being open to exploring this—it shows a real willingness to try and make changes, even when it feels like you’ve already tried so much. Would it be helpful to review your sleep data to see if it brings up any thoughts or connections you might not have noticed before? If not, that's absolutely okay, and we can approach this in other ways too.

Since reviewing your sleep data might not be an option right now, let's explore other areas like your routine or ways you wind down at the end of the day. For example, have you noticed anything about your evenings that might be affecting how you fall asleep? Or do you think creating a new evening habit might help calm your mind before bed?

Sorry, I accidentally wrote the response meant for me! Let me rewrite the response properly:

Are you open to reviewing my sleep data?
